awd_titl_txt: III: Small: Adopting Machine Learning Techniques for Big Spatial and Spatio-temporal Data and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Motivated by the ubiquity and magnitude of spatial and location data collected from myriad of devices, including, cell phones, GPS-enabled vehicles, and satellites, this award aims to take advantage of such data to enhance the scalability, accuracy, and usability of various artificial intelligence and machine learning techniques. This will advance the state-of-the-art of these techniques not only to accommodate more applications where spatial data is predominant (e.g., transportation, meteorology, and agriculture), but also to current applications that deal with spatial data (e.g., census, knowledge-base construction).

This award adopts machine learning techniques for big spatial and spatio-temporal data and applications in two orthogonal, but related, directions. First, injecting the spatial awareness inside machine learning techniques and applications, which would result in a higher accuracy for such applications. Second, taking advantage of the recent advances in machine learning techniques to boost the usability, scalability, and accuracy of long lasting spatial and spatio-temporal data analysis techniques. Towards its goal, this award exploits three main research topics: (1) Developing the concept and building Spatial Markov Logic Network (SMLN) by injecting the spatial awareness inside Markov Logic Network. (2) Leveraging the developed SMLN to build the first open-source system for a spatially-aware knowledge base construction system. (3) Leveraging the developed SMLN to increase the accuracy, scalability, and usability of several long lasting spatial analysis problems, including spatial autologistic regression, spatial classification, and Bayesian networks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has combined two important areas that were traditionally seen as parallel, namely, machine learning and spatial data/applications. In particular, the field of machine learning has witnessed an increasing interest with the wide spectrum of practical applications that benefit from it. Meanwhile, the recent proliferation in the amounts of spatial and spatio-temporal data produced from several devices, ranging from smart phones to space telescopes, has triggered various applications that call for using machine learning techniques as a means of spatial data analysis. This project has taken a very different approach in combining spatial applications with machine learning. Instead of directly applying machine learning to spatial applications, this project has injected spatial awareness into basic machine learning techniques, as a means of boosting their accuracy when dealing with spatial data. To this end, the project has made fundamental contributions to the machine learning techniques making them spatially aware and practical contributions to spatial applications allowing them to get the full potential of machine learning techniques.

With its new approach, the project was able to: (a) boost the accuracy of both knowledge-based construction and data cleaning systems by embedding spatial-awareness into their core machine learning methods, making them aware with the distinguishing characteristics of spatial data, and hence was able to make more accurate decisions, (b) scale up machine learning techniques as spatial-awareness and filters where embedded early in their execution process, and hence it was possible to exploit their use in solving long-lasting spatial analysis problems that was not possible to solve before due to limited scalability.

The project has supported four PhD students. One PhD student has already graduated with a dissertation that was Honorable Mention for the University of Minnesota Best Dissertation Award. The project has produced several papers and demos published in top-tier conferences and journals for both the database systems and spatial computing research communities. Results of the project have been presented through various invited keynotes and tutorials at major conferences. A major journal special issue was dedicated to the topic of the project, attracting a large number of papers from the research community worldwide, showing the impact and awareness that this project has made to the research community.
